text: -Hi! This is so weird! This is the weirdest introduction and my teeth are brown.
Oh god!
We're with Bobby Belote, who mans the "Shop Awesome," as I have dubbed it, here up in the Interactives.
So he does interactive museum exhibit things, and we're playing with a heat camera, and I learned that I have a terrible circulation!

- I can tell your surface temperature.
- Oh.
- It says—only the surface— so I know your forehead's 91.85. Your nose: 80... 80 degrees.
- I like doing this . You can put your hands on the face...
and then AULGGGHH. It looks like blood streaks.

- It's because you have the icy fingers.
- I know, my hands are so cold.
This is incredible! You can draw stuff on your forehead!
So how did you get into this?

- I have a weird background. I have degrees, a bachelor's in painting and art history. And then my master's is in new media art.
- Oh, nice!

- But, like I have this kind of vague, like I'm good at woodworking. I learned a lot about microcontrollers in school and doing low voltage circuitry.
- Cool.

- That kind of like, translated really well into this museum space.
- Gosh, this is... you just get to play all day long.
- This is amazing! This is the kind of stuff that I never understood about technology.
I look at something like this and I have no idea how circuits work. You just got into this just from playing around?
- Well, I was doing art stuff. I was doing, like, kinetic sculptures and kinetic video art and stuff.
So I was, like, learning how to do actuation through the art stuff and then I just developed all these skills.

And like, I didn't know how to monetize it, so I was like, "What could I do?"
- "I gotta get a job!"
So what else have you been working on up here?
- We want to demonstrate how the muscle connects to a bone at different points along the bone. There's my fake bone I made.

- Nice. I saw you printing this.
- Yeah, on the ShopBot.
- Yeah. ShopBot.

- So there's different leverage at work, so when it's close to the joint, it's harder to lift, but you have a greater range of motion.
- Ohh.

- And then you use my cool motor thing.
- Woah!

- 'Cause further away from the joint, it's much easier, but you have less range of motion.
- Ohhhh.
You play with buttons and things and you just get to experiment all day.
- Yeah, I made a circuit board and then I have a motor in there.
- That's—I don't even understand how you do it. I'm so amazed right now.

- You want to see the back part?
- Yeah!

- There's another one of my circuit boards I made. So, except there's a sensor here, a proximity sensor so it can tell when the arm's going up.
- Okay. Wow.

- So the arm goes up, the sensor goes off and it knows not to let the motor go.
- Ohhh.

- So I have the motor mounted onto the same rod that the arm is on so the drive mechanism kind of just travels with it.
- Wow.
- And then the buttons are hooked up. They go underneath. There's more sensors on the arm, too, that tell it when the— when it's at the ends,

so it doesn't try to overextend and over-torque it.
- Yeah. That's cool!
So do you come up with these ideas for the interactives, or does somebody kind of tell you what they want to happen and you say, "I can do that," or, "that's impossible?"
- Well, it's more of a collaborative process. So like, at the very early stages of the development, the interactives team will get together with the development team,

and they'll be like, "yeah, this is kind of the general theme of what we're looking at for the show. Do you have any ideas for this kind of stuff? We want to focus on this element of stuff to teach kids about."
So we're like, "Uh, we can try this, try that," and then... it's a really iterer proc—iterive—iterive—iterative! Ugh, I can't talk.

Iterative process, where you kind of, like, develop ideas.
- And bounce them back and forth and kinda figure out what works? That's so much fun.
- I work with the researchers. So I'll get a drawing like that, about, like, how things are supposed to move.

So I'll make like an early prototype.
- Okay, like this thing?
- So this is my first "Dunk."

- Aw, so this is Dunkleosteus, this is that prehistoric... it was a fish, right? Prehistoric fish?
- Yes, giant armored fish, had an armored eyeball, and the skull was like...

- This, it's like this big. Yeah.
- Must be 4 feet across, 6 feet tall.
So this first one, I kind of just based it off the drawing I had. I kind of got a couple things wrong, like this is not supposed to be static.

So like, we wrote little notes. It says that this is a muscle actually, not a bone.
- Ohh.

- And, you know, how much the muscle needs to contract. So I made a more advanced model.
- Nice.

- So I kind of refined the drawing, made it look more like a Dunk. And then I kind of made it so that the muscles will slide correctly.
- Yeah. Well that looks... yeah.

- And the bottom one.
- He's going. Oh, 'cause it can, like, shoot its jaw forward.

- Yeah, the whole head just kinda shoots forward.
- Like, "HUURGH."
- Now, like, for the Dunk right now, I'm working on getting the final one made—or the final prototype made.
Basically at this stage, I'm kind reinforcing—I'm making reinforcements for weak points in the interactive 'cause I need to make it really tough so it lasts a long time.

And I'm also, like, including little springs so it'll return. So that one's just real simple—trying to like, proof the concept, trying to get the motion right.
- Yeah.
- So this one has more of the bells and whistles, where it has, like, the spring returns and reinforced joints and stuff like that to make sure it lasts a long time.

- Also I had to research material, like, I went through a bunch of different iterations of different materials before I found this.
- This... plastic?
- Yeah, it's a polyethylene, like a high density, rigid, polyethylene. It's a really low-friction surface, has a high impact strength, so it can take a lot of abuse.

- Yeah. This has to last for quite a while, I mean, and is this going to part of the traveling exhibit?
- Mhmm.

- So this is gonna go all over the country, and all over the world.
- Mhmm.
- And kids and adults and obnoxious people in their mid-twenties like me are going to play with it for decades to come.

- And people yank on these things during, like, public tests.
- Yeah.

- There's a lever, like— I saw one lady, she like braced herself and, like, yanked up with her full force on the leverage interactive.
- Wow.
- The first time. She didn't even do, like, a test pull. She's like, "Okay, I'm gonna, like, get this," and like, yanked the crap out of it.

- Wow, so you have to put these things under quite a bit of abuse.
- Yeah.
- Yeah. Well, if you ever need, like, a test audience, have me come up here and I'll go crazy.
- I don't know, 6-year-olds are the most destructive force on Earth.

- Not hurricanes, not volcanoes.
- They're the gold standard, yeah.
- 6-year-olds.

So the sling-jaw's, like, another kind of fish. That's a modern fish.
- Yeah. But it can launch its mouth out really far.
- That's insane.

- Boink!
- Fun!

This way? Woahp, woahp.
- Go up. Go up.

- Did I break it? There we go.
- Yeah, I haven't put the stops in yet.
- Oh! See? It's not Emily-proof yet. Ulgh!
Look at it go! You should put like a worm or something. What do these guys eat?
- Yeah, we're gonna put something there. Some little f— maybe a little shrimp or something.

- I'm just gonna come up here when you're not here and then you're gonna walk in and I'm just gonna be playing.
- "Why are all my things broken?!"
- "Emily...."
Woo!
I just, like, am amazed that my hair is cold, and the little thing, and my braid-thing and my glasses, and I can take my glasses off—
Oh, Emily has her glasses off for the first time on The Brain Scoop! I have awkward, like, eye spots.

- You can see your eyelashes.
- Can you?!
- Mhmm.

- I'm a pretty princess.
- They're slightly purple.
- Well, thank you for taking the time to talk with us today. Like I said, I'm gonna be up here all the time, playing with all of the things and the interactives.
- And nooooooo! It's like that scene in Macbeth, where Lady Macbeth has the blood on her hands and she's like, "Ahh it's everywhere!"

- I think my hands are too warm to do that.
- Yeah, not me. I don't have...

My thumb for whatever reason is really warm.
- This is what my hair would look like with frosted tips.

- I don't know if that's a good look for you.
- I don't think so either.
- But anyway, yeah. Well, thanks, thanks for talking! Say goodbye! Goodbye!
